 > be consolidates under one

 > if code != 200:

Its because they are actually two different scenarios. A code status which is non-200 like 400/404/422 for external events is still considered a successful send/receival whereas a "None" code means something went wrong when compiling results and the status of the event is neither success nor failed. See https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=run-events-detail#id395 for more details. This is why we return False for code None and True for code!=200 cases from this function.

This has changed now, by [1], such that you'll *never* get the 404. If the (single) event bounces, you'll get 207 with an individual event code. The way this is coded, I believe that means it'll return True in that case. Where/how is that return value used?

For the sake of form, it wouldn't be a terrible idea to refactor this code to work properly against the new behavior, which was always the intent. Since L84 was unreachable before anyway, this shouldn't affect prod code.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698037/

> In the non-400+ case the possible expected values from this API are
 > 200 and 207, and the API ref says:
 > 
 > > A 200 will be returned if all events succeeded, 207 will be
 > returned if some events could not be processed. The code attribute
 > for the event will explain further what went wrong.
 > 
 > Since we're only posting one event and expecting to get back one
 > event in the response, is it possible to get a 207?

no its not possible.

 > But even if we
 > did, it doesn't really matter right? Because we're checking the
 > code on the event, not the code on the response itself.

correct. Btw, like noted before atm since we have bug 1839009 in nova, we would always get only one of the following responses:

1) a code=200 and status_code=200 / when success - this will have L86 as debug
2) or a HTTPNotFound with status_code=404 / when its a failure irrespective of the type (https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e3a55493ba0cb405f14b9090282d93eb230c5715/nova/api/openstack/compute/server_external_events.py#L147) - this will have L73 as error.

cloudbaseinit/metadata/services/osconfig.message:
This message can be really confusing. Maybe the instance is not even using a config drive.

One idea would be to have something like "Looking for Openstack configdrive. Expecting drive label '%s'.". For each drive you may log "Found drive '%s' having label '%s'". It does seem a bit verbose but it's probably fine for a debug message (maybe that's the main reason we haven't added it already, invalid config drive images aren't common).

If the drive does have the expected label but you can't find the file that you're looking for, you may log another message (maybe even a warning).

Ideally, those checks should be in the parent class so that other config drive based services can benefit from it (e.g. azure, ovf, etc).

It's probably worth mentioning that this will be logged for all the available volumes even when not actually using configdrives.

How about rephrasing it a bit, something like:
"Looking for a Config Drive with label: '%s'. Found mismatching label: '%s'".
Looking for a Config Drive with label '%s' on '%s'. Found mismatching label '%s'.
Looking for a Config Drive with label '%s'. Found mismatching label '%s' on '%s'.

This command displays the aggregated counts of critical, major, minor and warning alarms across all subclouds.

doc/source/cli_ref/system.rst.message:
The certificate management commands allows the user to install custom certificates for a variety of use cases within StarlingX.  The user can install custom certificates for 
- StarlingX REST APIs and StarlingX Horizon Webserver, 
- StarlingX Local Docker Registry, 
- OpenStack REST APIs and OpenStack Horizon Webserver, and
- StarlingX Trusted Certificate Authority(s).

The local docker registry management commands enable the removing of images and freeing the disk resources they are consuming from the Local Docker Registry.  This would be required if the local docker registry's file system, docker-distribution, becomes full.

These commands manage filesystems on the hosts; primarily supporting the ability to re-size the filesystems.  The 'host-fs-list/show/modify' commands manage un-synchronized filesystems on controllers and computes.  The 'controllerfs-list/show/modify' commands manage drbd-synchronized filesystems on the controllers.

The following set of commands enable configuration of 
- basic system attributes, 
- the OAM IP Address(es), Subnet and Gateway, 
- remote dns servers for StarlingX hosts to use, and
- time synchronization protocols; i.e. NTP and/or PTP.

Service parameters provide a generic mechanism for configuring a variety of configurable parameters of StarlingX, these include:
- http and https ports, 
- starlingx horizon authentication lockout parameters,
- starlingx keystone token expiry, 
- starlingx host management configurable parameters such as heartbeat intervals, host boot timeouts, etc.

The 'host-sensor' commands provide the ability to display the sensors collected from hosts over IPMI, define thresholds and configure the behaviour (e.g. ignore, log, alarm, reset, etc.) when thresholds are crossed.

StarlingX provides an application package management which combines Airship Armada and Kubernetes Helm.  StarlingX Application Management provides 'system' helm overrides to automatically apply starlingx applications appropriately for the particular starlingx configuration currently running, as well as managing 'user'-specified helm overrides.

StarlingX supports a simple SNMPv2c Agent; all fault management alarms and events are sent out as SNMP Traps and SNMP Gets are support on an Active Alarm Table and a Historical Events Table.  These commands support the configuration of the SNMP Agent; i.e. configuring a community string for SNMP GETs and configuring one or more trap destinations for SNMP TRAPs.

The following commands manage the general configuration of a StarlingX host.  This includes assignment of cpu cores to platform or hosted applications, the configuration of amount and size of memory huge pages, and the configuration of Kubernetes node labels.
The following commands provide operational host commands.  These include administratively taking a host in and out of service (lock/unlock), reseting, rebooting and powering on and off.

The following set of commands manage the display and configuration of host interfaces.   The 'host-port-list/show' commands display the L1 host ports and their attributes.   The 'host-if-add/list/show/modify/delete' commands display and configure the L2 host interfaces; i.e. supporting ethernet, vlan and lag type L2 host interfaces.
The following commands define types of L2 platform networks, assignment of L2 platform networks to interfaces and configuration of L3 IP Interfaces and Routing.

The following commands define types of L2 data networks and assignment of L2 data networks to interfaces.  Data networks represent the underlying L2 networks for Kubernetes SRIOV/PCIPASSTHROUGH network attachments or for OpenStack tenant networks.
The following commands enable the display and configuration of host disks, volume groups and disk partitions.

I don't have the answer for this, but I think it would be good to update the help info here so that we better understand why triggers were included in the first place.

They don't seem to be used for anything (and don't end up in job inventories), but maybe there are plans to make use of this somehow? If there is no plan for using this info maybe help should include a deprecation notice and the flag will be removed. If there is a plan we can expand on that here and maybe not make it optional depending on the plan?

In the past there were already some discussions about making jobs aware of the trigger. All of them were rejected because zuul is meant to be a git driven system where it doesn't matter how a job was triggered. Judging from this design philosophy the trigger won't be used in future as well and if that changes the enqueue could hard code a 'manual' trigger inside zuul.

Nevertheless I think we should deprecate (and just ignore) the trigger argument.

I don't know the exact history but I assume the idea was to mimic a real event, which always has a trigger by definition.  It turns out providing the project, pipeline & change info is enough for zuul to enqueue an event.

Should we instead define a default "manual" or "admin" trigger that covers CLI/GUI events to be consistent with other triggers?

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Let's go with something a bit more helpful. How about:

  Don't treat PCI devices as PFs when no VFs are enabled

  When nova detects that a PCI device has SR-IOV PF capabilities,
  it special cases it. Among other things, it means it will not
  be possible to attach the PCI device to an instance using a
  PCI alias *unless* "'device_type': 'type-PF'" is configured
  in the '[pci] alias' config option [1]. This behavior is
  intended to prevent users attaching the PF of a PCI device
  when they actually intended to attach one of the many VFs.
  However, there isn't really a reason to do this if the PCI
  device in question doesn't have an VFs enabled. Stop doing
  this by checking if the device has VFs enabled before marking
  it as a special 'type-PF' device.

  [1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694522/

swiftclient/client.py.message:
I have one reservation about using __del__ -- IIRC, we won't have much control over when the cleanup happens, right? It's just kinda "whenever the garbage collector gets around to it" and in the mean time, the socket's still going to leak.

How do you feel about cleaning up the connection as soon as we're done with it? Something like

diff --git a/swiftclient/client.py b/swiftclient/client.py
index 4be2e2d..e3d110c 100644
--- a/swiftclient/client.py
+++ b/swiftclient/client.py
@@ -1266,6 +1266,8 @@ def head_object(url, token, container, name, http_conn=None,
     conn.request(method, path, '', headers)
     resp = conn.getresponse()
     body = resp.read()
+    if not http_conn:
+        conn.close()
     http_log(('%s%s' % (url.replace(parsed.path, ''), path), method,),
              {'headers': headers}, resp, body)
     if resp.status < 200 or resp.status >= 300:

Of course, it'll be a larger change -- it affects every top-level function :-/ -- but it has the benefit of releasing resources immediately.

So it's not really leaking until it's garbage collected because it would be available for reuse because of keepalive.  The issue here is is really that we never properly close the session.  You don't want to close the connection every request because you'll take a perf hit for more complex usage.

What does this empty clause do?

I meant to write a diatribe on the evils of "except Exception" here, let the hate flow freely. But if the body is empty, perhaps we can just avoid the issue altogether.
if it's already closed it throws an exception. This is to just drop the exception
No exception is thrown if an already-closed session is closed again. But even if it were, the specific exception should be caught and not every one.

octavia/amphorae/drivers/haproxy/rest_ap.message: I've started to really dislike our use of these aliases everywhere, it's really not *so* long to just use the whole path, lol
It is unclear to be when exactly to use DEGRADED operating status. I'd tend to say a load balancer with child resources not in the desired state should be marked as DEGRADED?

That is a fair statement based on the API-REF.
Currently we are not bubbling DEGRADED up to the LB except when a listener is out of connection slots or a pool is degraded.
I have opened https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2006981 to track this and fix it in a follow up patch.

ugh, it hurts me that "delete_listener" doesn't take a listener ID. T_T

but, I think this may be problematic? will this delete any existing listeners? so what if there was one listener we can't update because of barbican, and that is the only listener -- will we delete it instead of just leaving it alone? is that possible?

Yes, if it was successful fetching them above, but if the listener isn't in the listeners_to_update list, we failed to fetch the required certs/keys.
Also remember, this can be called for any update to the LB configuration, including a change that did not modify the certificates or even a failover.
Aren't the cert payloads already fetched and validated by the time this is called?

Yeah, so this method is a nuke and replace type of deal. It fully re-deploys the configuration (It is one file now). So, if we fell down here with listeners_to_update = None, there are no functional/valid listeners on the LB. We don't want to leave an old configuration running (or looping attempting to run) that is invalid. Otherwise you would not be able to delete a listener if the certs are missing from barbican.

  # get resp.body from GET /v3/{project_id}/os-services
  sresp = json.loads(resp.body)
  services = sresp['services']
  backends = [ s for s in services where s['binary'] == 'cinder-volume' ]
  be_index = { b['host'].split('@')[1] : b for b in backends }

  # get resp.body from GET /v3/{project_id}/scheduler-stats/get_pools?detail=true
  presp = json.loads(resp.body)
  pools = presp['pools']

  # load in the availability zones
  for p in pools:
      p['availability_zone'] = 
          be_index[p['capabilities']['volume_backend_name']]['zone']

Which gives you the response you describe below.

specs/stein/approved/image-encryption.rs.message: s/disk/disk image/
Done
might be more common to say "A user wants to snapshot a server that uses an unencrypted disk image and encrypt the snapshot before storage".
Done
perhaps more common to say "A user wants to snapshot a server that uses an encrypted disk image"?
Done
Why re-encrypt? if the target is already encrypted, why do the encryption again?
Done

Simply because the encryption mechanisms differ. Our proposed solution specifies a GPG-based AES256 encryption. The encryption of ephemeral storage disks currently supported is LUKS-based aes-xts-plain64 encryption. LUKS is substantially different from the GPG format, thus one needs to be transformed into the other. Essentially we consider images and ephemeral disks (or volumes) to be entirely separate resources that may be transformed into one another. Currently, both volume and ephemeral storage encryption is LUKS-based so we could theoretically re-use this but what if other formats are involved as target or source? We would suggest against limiting the possibilities of the image encryption concept by binding it to the currently used technologies for other resources. If you had a LUKS-based image encryption format, transformation into any other format would be really dirty because:

* you would need root permissions for cryptsetup to open up the LUKS container as a dmcrypt devmapper endpoint

* a dmcrypt devmapper endpoint needs to exist while the image is being read from - this exposes the image data for the root user, kinda like creating a temporary unencrypted copy of the image
Does streaming means that the image content is decrypted on the fly as the running server accessing content on the encrypted disk?
Done

No, at the time of the server start the decryption process has been finished already. Streaming in this context means the direct conversion of encrypted image into encrypted ephemeral disk prior to server start, avoiding the creation of temporary unencrypted files.

This is confusing to me. Are you saying that an image is only able to be encrypted/decrypted if it is of a particular container_format? This seems odd to me. Wouldn't the aspect of an image being encrypted or not be tangential to the container format it has? In other words, wouldn't the entire image object (all the bits of it, etc) be encrypted together as a single unit?

Yes, the whole image data is to be encrypted. Isn't that what the container_format describes? The encapsulated disk_format may vary but the outermost structure is the encrypted format. We currently plan to add a "os_decrypt_container_format" property as the Glance guys suggested, which describes the format after decryption. I guess this is what you are looking for?

On a side note: making encrypted images have a dedicated container_format simplifies the code handling them, since they will most likely always require special treatment. The container_format would be accessible upfront without crawling through the additional metadata properties, reducing code complexity.

I don't see a mention of this new image type anywhere? Per my comment above on line 148, I'm wondering why there would be a new image type versus some separate image property that indicates that the image bits have been encrypted with some particular encryption algorithm and key location.

what does this mean?

The attribute image ancryption key will contain a key id (id in Barbican) which is then used to encrypt any image created from the server (temporary images and snapshots). When creating such images, the key id is also written to its metadata in glance. In conclusion, we have a key id for a key which was not yet used to encrypt an image - so we can easily change it, if needed. Allowing this would also give users the opportunity to set an image encryption key for other servers (created from unencrypted images). Images from these servers would then also be encrypted. 
And if a user wants to use another key at some point, it would be possible to simply change the key id (allowing key rotation).

oh, I thought we could do this streaming-ly.

The decryption does happen streaming-ly.
The current state is, that nova caches a glance image (also to check the signature) and copies it into the ephemeral storage disk.
With our image encryption, the cached image is still encrypted. We decrypt it at the point it is streamed into the ephemeral storage disk.
Without streaming-ly decryption, we would have to create a second temporary unencrypted image file. That is what we avoid.
ditto

It's the same way like for the decryption.
The current state is, that nova creates a temporary file and copies the ephemeral storage image into this file. After that a signature could be generated.
With our image encryption, we would encrypt the data while streaming into this temporary file. Thus having an encrypted temporary file, which then could also be signed.
Again without streaming-ly encryption we would have to create a second unencrypted temporary file for the image data. Which is what we avoid.

Doesn't this defeat the stated goal of leaving the image encrypted in caches? With this approach, the only place it's stored encrypted is on the glance servers. The compute hosts are arguably the least secure nodes in the system, but they have the image stored unencrypted at rest?

I would think that in order to make this actually work the way a user expects, the decryption step needs to be on the flatten operation, and that encrypted images are always flattened out of the cache during boot or something. That's a bit larger of a step than what is described here, which is just to transparently decrypt during download, AFAICT.

If you're not talking about decryption during download (as you state here), then this should be changed to reflect what actually happens (in libvirt at least, not sure about the others) where the base image is downloaded in its entirety, and then copied, flattened, or CoW'd to create the instance's disk.

Does this happen generically in the ComputeManager or in the virt driver code? Because if the latter, we would want a compute capability flag/trait per driver so we that we can filter hosts properly during scheduling so we don't send these types of images to computes with hypervisor drivers that don't support them.

It's worth noting here that encrypted LVM offers no additional protection over unencrypted LVM in practise: we give the key to dm-crypt, then present the unencrypted device as a device-mapper block device on the compute host. Any attack which compromises the encrypted data also has access to the unencrypted data, so this is literally useless.

If ephemeral storage is a related goal, I strongly suggest throwing the existing work in LVM away and starting again. Something based on QEMU native encryption would be a much better bet.

@Luzi, the traits in that file are for filtering support by disk_format. IIUC you're using container_format to indicate 'encrypted' - when unencrypted, the disk would still be in one of those existing TYPE_* formats. Do I have that right?

If so, you'll want to introduce a trait in a different "namespace" to avoid confusion - e.g. COMPUTE_IMAGE_CONTAINER_ENCRYPTED - and add new request filter logic that converts container_format='encrypted' to trait:COMPUTE_IMAGE_CONTAINER_ENCRYPTED=required. I'm not sure how hard it would be to encompass filtering for *all* container types, but at the very least you could just special-case 'encrypted' and ignore the rest.

It's probably appropriate to fold that logic into the existing require_image_type_support filter [1], which is the one that deals with the COMPUTE_IMAGE_TYPE_* traits you pointed out. As luck would have it, that filter and its conf switch were named "*_image_type_*", which is generic enough to encompass both disk_format and container_format :) (It would have been nice if the traits were named COMPUTE_IMAGE_DISK_FORMAT_*, but alas...)

My only concern with reusing the same filter is that IMO we should *always* be imposing this new logic, not forcing the operator to switch on that scheduler filter to be not-broken. But (again IMO) the same argument applies to the existing logic there, so meh.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/commit/877a78a63b13dc6599aed7c152b26b25501a52e8/nova/scheduler/request_filter.py#L124

The encryption of ephemeral storage is a separate concern. Currently it is possible for LVM to have encrypted ephemeral storage.

In the case of using GPG-encrypted Images a full copy would be needed.
If there would be something like native LUKS-encrypted ephemeral storage in Ceph. We could think about adding another "driver" or encryption mechanism - namely LUKS - for the Image encryption. Because in that case copy-on-write would be possible with both image and ephemeral storage encrypted in the same way. 
But that would be a very specific use case: just for Ceph. We want to provide a more general approach for all kind of use cases and combinations of Glance storage backends and hypervisors. Plus ephemeral storage encryption in Ceph is currently not implemented.

No, this is explicitly added to nova, because we want to use this key for encryption, whenever an image is created from a server. We explained it in
the key-lock paragraph.

The createBackup server action also creates snapshots - will that be changed here? Or will that just not support encrypted snapshots?

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#create-server-back-up-createbackup-action

I think for the most part we've been trying to essentially freeze changes to that API since it's purely an orchestration API that isn't really necessary to be part of compute since users can replicate the same thing externally.

First: there won‘t be any changes to the API – we do all the decryption and encryption decisions in the backend based on present metadata objects.
Second: the createBackup API is essentially a wrapper around the same functionality which createImage uses under the hood (snapshot function). Since we propose to use the „image_key_id“ property for the snapshot step, the encryption should happen automatically regardless which of the APIs was used.
I think appropriate measures should be done to make sure the VMs land on a hypervisor that can store data encrypted (and figuring out some sort of solution for things like rbd)

If the images are stored encrypted and decrypted only when creating an instance's disk, then another performance impact is that instances from these images take up more disk than expected. It also means that users control whether or not a spawn takes a little bit of disk on the compute, or a lot. And, it definitely impacts the time to spawn, not only because of the decryption but also the IO involved in copying all the data.

Anything that involves changes to behavior on the nova-compute service will be impacted by this, e.g. a request to a snapshot a server and create an encrypted snapshot image out of it, if that happens on the compute and the compute is old (Stein in this case for rolling upgrade support), then you can't support the operation. Would the API check the compute service version and fail if it's not new enough and the API can know ahead of time that the compute is being asked to do an encrypted snapshot? Otherwise the API will happily accept the request and pass it to an old compute that won't honor it.

Similar issues for creating a server from an encrypted image - how are we going to handle those? There are a few options:

1. Do things the old school openstack way and just don't care and let things fail in the compute, but that sucks.

2. Don't allow creating servers from encrypted images until all computes in the deployment are upgraded. That's a bigger hammer but we've done it for other things (I think trusted image certificate IDs is one example).

3. Do something with scheduler filtering such that if we're asked to boot from an encrypted image, we only do it on computes that support it (so anything upgraded and with a virt driver that supports encrypted images - which I'm guessing would be only the libvirt driver to start since we're talking about using os-brick?). This is the most flexible and also makes sense once we're past Train and all computes are expected to be upgraded, but not all virt drivers support this feature. In this case, the drivers could expose a compute capability trait to placement and we could have a pre-request scheduler filter [1] that translates a request to use an encrypted image to a required trait on the RequestSpec so the scheduler only asks placement for hosts that support encrypted images.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/configuration/schedulers.html#prefiltering
Thats a good argument. Of course number three would be the way to choose, as it would also cover the compute capability trait. I will add this to the spec.
i like option #3

...to libvirt? All the drivers? The image handling code is not fully generic and virt-independent. I'm assuming you want to implement this first for libvirt, but it needs to be done in a way that works for the other drivers. Can we get some input from the others about whether or not they can support decryption in the same way?

Just to be clear on all of the above... If the image has something sensitive in it, then it's safe until this step (or the download step, depending on the answers to the above). I guess it seems like a bit of a false security blanket to keep the thing locked up super tight until someone boots it, at which time the secrets are all dumped on disk in plaintext.

It seems like it would be a lot better to use some sort of natively encrypted disk format so that it's safe at rest in all the places.
